title: Dmitry Solovyev
text:
Statistician | Data Scientist | Policy Analyst

About me
I am Dmitry Solovyev, a statistician, data scientist, and policy analyst with experience in data analysis and policy evaluation. My work spans social-economic, healthcare and international domains, where I apply quantitative and qualitative methods to address complex policy challenges.
As a statistician, I’ve focused on data integrity and analytical accuracy. My notable project in this domain involved developing a machine learning model to classify the reliability of COVID-19 data, incorporating time-series cross-validation and visualization techniques to ensure model robustness and reliability.
As a data scientist, I have leveraged my skills to enhance open access to information. A key project was contributing to the development of a public policy database, aiming to facilitate research through an open-source platform. This initiative has proven vital for researchers seeking accessible, comprehensive data for analysis.
As a policy analyst, I’ve applied my analytical skills towards the improvement of public service operations and policy reforms. Through the study of personnel policy in public agencies, my colleagues and I conducted observational research and interviews across several federal ministries, leading to the adoption of new guidelines based on our findings. Additionally, a comparative study on national diplomatic service reforms, in which we investigated the ways to adopt best foreign practices, was presented to the Ministry for Foreign Affairs and has contributed to ongoing policy discussion and development.
Throughout my academic and professional career, I’ve developed project management and cross-functional collaboration skills. My role often involves presenting findings and insights to target audiences, ensuring clarity and actionable understanding. I drive projects from conception through to completion, effectively communicate complex information, and foster productive communication.
In addition, I am fluent in English, Russian and Ukrainian.


My education

MS in Statistics, Oregon State University, 2022-2024
Master of Public Policy, Oregon State University, 2021-2023
Bachelor of Political Science, Lomonosov Moscow State University, 2012-2016



My skills
Statistics and data analysis: R (tidyverse, ggplot2, dplyr), Python (sklearn, pandas, numpy, plotly, seaborn, scipy, igraph), SQL
Cloud: BigQuery, pyspark
Visualization: Tableau
Other software: ArcGIS, NetLogo, Atlas.ti, SPSS, STATA, Qualtrics

title: Projects
text:
Reliability of COVID-19 data

R code
In this project, I aimed to create a machine learning model to classify unreliable COVID-19 data on mortality and spreading rates, evaluated model performance with time-series cross-validation and visualized training and validation results and implement a synthetic control method to evaluate the effectiveness of a policy intervention in addressing the pandemic.



Reforms of Diplomatic Agencies in the Face of New Foreign Policy Challenges

Click to view
Analytical review of reforming diplomatic agencies based on the transformation experience of the diplomatic service in different countries over the past ten years. This review describes the global and national drivers of reforms, the details of their preparation and implementations, and the best practices applied by diplomatic agencies seeking to adapt to changing international foreign policies.



Russian COVID-19 Humanitarian Aid Database

Click to view
Open-access dataset on Russian COVID-19 Humanitarian Aid as a part of a larger public policy database, aiming to facilitate research through an open-source platform.



Battleships Game Strategies Simulation

R code
Battleships a strategy-type guessing game for two players, played on ruled grids (paper or board) on which each player’s fleet of warships is marked. Before the start, players deploy their ships of different sizes on the grid, and the locations of the fleets are concealed from the other players. Players are trying to guess the location of enemy ships and hit them by taking turns. In this simulation project, I am investigating the most efficient ship placement strategies that would increase the chances of survival.
